quiz.title: Grade 12 Physics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 6, Quiz 4: Advanced AC Circuits - Reactance & Phase
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: In a purely inductive circuit, what is the phase relationship between current ($I$) and voltage ($V$)?
questions.explanation: Inductors oppose changes in current: $V_L = L(di/dt)$. For sinusoidal AC, this creates 90° phase lag. Mnemonic: ELI (Emf/Voltage leads Current in Inductor).

questions.question: What happens to the inductive reactance ($X_L$) if the frequency of the AC source is doubled?
questions.explanation: Inductive reactance: $X_L = 2\pi f L$, directly proportional to frequency $f$. Doubling $f$ doubles $X_L$. High $f$ → high opposition to current change.

questions.question: In a purely capacitive circuit, what is the phase relationship between current and voltage?
questions.explanation: Capacitors oppose voltage changes: $I_C = C(dv/dt)$. For sinusoidal AC, current leads voltage by 90°. Mnemonic: ICE (Current leads Emf/Voltage in Capacitor).

questions.question: Which component acts as a "short circuit" to high-frequency AC signals?
questions.explanation: Capacitive reactance $X_C = 1/(2\pi f C) \to 0$ as $f \to \infty$. At very high frequencies, capacitors effectively become short circuits (low impedance).

questions.question: The total opposition to current in an RLC (Resistor-Inductor-Capacitor) circuit is called:
questions.explanation: Impedance $Z$ combines resistance $R$ and reactance $X = X_L - X_C$: $Z = \sqrt{R^2 + (X_L - X_C)^2}$. Measured in ohms ($\Omega$), it's AC equivalent of DC resistance.

questions.question: At "Resonance" in a series RLC circuit, which of the following is true?
questions.explanation: Resonance occurs when $X_L = X_C$ (at $f_0 = 1/(2\pi\sqrt{LC})$). Reactances cancel: $Z = R$ (minimum impedance), current maximum, phase angle $\phi = 0°$ (voltage and current in phase).

questions.question: What is the unit for both Inductive Reactance and Capacitive Reactance?
questions.explanation: Both $X_L$ and $X_C$ are measured in ohms ($\Omega$). $X_L = 2\pi f L$: $[\text{Hz}] \times [\text{H}] = [\text{s}^{-1}] \times [\text{V·s/A}] = [\text{V/A}] = [\Omega]$. Similarly for $X_C$.

questions.question: In which type of pure AC circuit is the average power consumption zero?
questions.explanation: Inductors and capacitors store and return energy each cycle (reactive power). Average (real) power $P_{avg} = V_{rms}I_{rms}\cos\phi$, where $\cos\phi = 0$ for pure $L$ or $C$ ($\phi = \pm90^\circ$).

questions.question: The "Power Factor" of a circuit is defined as the ratio of:
questions.explanation: Power factor $= \cos\phi = R/Z$, where $\phi$ is phase angle between voltage and current. Range: 0 to 1. Measures efficiency of power delivery; low PF means more current needed for same real power.

questions.question: If an AC circuit has a frequency of 100 Hz, what is the capacitive reactance of a $10\mu\text{F}$ capacitor? (Use $\pi \approx 3.14$)

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered AC circuit concepts including reactance, impedance, resonance, phase relationships, and power factor.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Strong understanding of AC circuit behavior. Review the frequency dependence of reactance and the conditions for resonance in RLC circuits.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) Phase relationships in inductive/capacitive circuits, 2) Reactance formulas ($X_L = 2\pi fL$, $X_C = 1/(2\pi fC)$), 3) Impedance and resonance concepts, 4) Power factor and energy storage.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the fundamentals: Review how inductors and capacitors respond to AC, the concepts of reactance vs. resistance, and basic phase relationships in AC circuits.
